ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about various topics in reproductive health, such as abortion, miscarriage, contraception, sterilization, reproductive technologies, etc. As part of the course, we also read two books which focused in-depth on one of these topics and wrote a paper about them. I was also introduced to primary source analysis and historical writing through the final paper due at the end of the semester.
Learned about the history of reproductive health and the feminist movements throughout the 19th and 20th century.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The readings were incredibly interesting, and if you think you'd like the course, the readings will be great! I feel like I've learned so much about the history of gynecology in the US. Unfortunately, the discussions were not incredibly interesting/engaging for me personally. This is obviously very dependent on the chemistry of seminar members and is made more difficult by zoom seminars. However, I found Professor Eisenberg sometimes tried too hard to force the conversation in certain directions. This sometimes made discussion awkward when people did not have a lot to say but were pushed away from pursuing the topics they were gravitating towards.
Amazing course, incredibly interesting, fabulous professor.  Take this class if you can!

A definite strength of this course is the assigned readings. Although the reading load was a lot, I could tell that Prof. Eisenberg spent a lot of time curating readings for each week, and none of the articles/books assigned felt useless or irrelevant (I feel this way sometimes in other seminars or history classes). Though I'm sure that the cohort of students each year bring a different flavor to this course, I think Prof. Eisenberg does well at facilitating discussion, keeping us on topic, and asking challenging questions to help us think more deeply about these topics instead of succumbing to popular opinion by default.
The class material was really interesting but it was kind of difficult to sit through a 2 hour lecture on zoom.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I really liked how Prof. Eisenberg changed his Zoom background instead of just screensharing slides-- this allowed me to stay on gallery view during class and see the other students' faces instead of just zoning out. I also appreciated how he took the time to ask for feedback regarding how he can make online teaching better during one-on-one conversations with his students-- not many teachers I know are eager to seek feedback from their students.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I highly recommend this course to anyone who is remotely interested in the subject matter. The material can be tough to get through sometimes (eugenic sterilization and medical experimentation on enslaved women are topics covered), but the thoughtful conversation had in discussion is well worth it. Also if you're looking for a writing credit this only has a midterm and a final paper (with occasional casual reading responses)
yes!! take this class. The Professor is amazing and you learn so much.

Yes! I came into this class knowing very little about reproductive health history, and I feel that I have left this class knowing not just more information but also equipped with the courage to engage in discussions about difficult topics (like abortion and sterilization) with respect and cognizance. I looked forward to attending this class every week, and the ~2 hours never felt like a long time due to how captivating the subject matter was and how engaged the other students were.
Yes, definitely take this course! It is really interesting and professor Eisenberg is really great.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
